posts.author: gralf
posts.post_text: April 10, 2016 at 8:21 PM#4Okay, I get it.But 80 macros?! Creating them is one part of the job. Firering the other one. If you do not want to create (e.g. by copy-paste a default-macro and edit afterwords) such a bunch of macros, it will be much less fun to control them in a live-show.How about this? Think in a matrix:1. create 8 macros to select the group of fixtures to controlEach of these macros will set a variable with the executor inside to control.2. create 10 macros to select the cue (i.e. color) and fire the cue in the executor depending on the variable set before.This makes it much more handy and even faster to find the right macro.First group of macro:----------------------setuservar $ex = 2.101----------------------Second group of macro:----------------------Goto cue 1 Executor $ex----------------------To create those macros by another macro called "wizard" simply use this snippet:----------------------Setvar $loop = -1[$loop==-1] Setuservar $loop = 1setuservar $exno = 100adduservar $exno = $loopassign macro $loop /cmd= "setuservar $ex = 2.$exno"adduservar $loop = 1[$loop<=10] top macro "wizard"------------------------This code is created from scratch and not tested but the concept might be clear.Please have a try...Gralf

posts.author: gralf
posts.post_text: April 10, 2016 at 9:07 PM#6On MA1 I had a similar problem and solved it like this:All Cues get a fade-time (e.g. 1sec) and the macro calls "goto cue 1 fade 1".To change the fading in speed just set the fader of the executor to rate with fader=rate=0  resulting in no fadetime. This works great.Maybe on MA2 you can combine the executors to a master-rate and assign this to one of the 100mm-fader.Perhaps macros could read the execfadetime and use it to control cuefading, but I don't have a specific code in mind for that.regardsGralf
